entry.title: üöÄ Introducing SCIM API for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2: Seamless User Sync between Source & Target
entry.content:
SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 now supports SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management) APIs, enabling seamless and secure user provisioning from SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) or Customer Identity Directory via SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS).

This integration simplifies identity lifecycle management, ensures compliance, and eliminates manual user creation in the target system (SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2).

To enable in your environment - Request you to create a SAP Support Ticket in Component - CEC-CRM

Its a Feature Flag currently - SCIM API in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is disabled by default.

SSC v2 SCIM API (Official API Documentation - not Released yet)

### Tenant Details but you need to pass the tenant id in the URL
GET {{SSCv2url}}/scim/v2/Users
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}

üö´Important Notes to keep in mind before enabling:

No Manual User Creation Allowed

This ensures that all user data is centrally managed and synchronized, maintaining consistency and reducing the risk of identity mismatches or unauthorized access.

Once SCIM-based provisioning is enabled in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2:

Manual user creation in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is disabled.

When using IPS (SCIM 2.0 based API), only users of type Employee are provisioned. This version introduces an enhanced SCIM API that no longer requires SAP Cloud Integration. It supports patch operations and provisioning of application-specific groups(Business Roles). In addition to pagination using startIndex and count, cursor-based pagination is also supported.

Why SCIM API Matters

SCIM is an open standard designed to automate the exchange of user identity information between identity providers and service providers. With SCIM support in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2, organizations can:

  • Automatically provision and de-provision users
  • Sync user attributes and roles
  • Ensure consistent identity governance
  • Reduce administrative overhead

Benefits of SCIM Integration

  • Automated User Lifecycle Management
  • Improved Security & Compliance
  • Centralized Identity Governance
  • Reduced Manual Effort
  • Scalable for Large Enterprises

Integration Flow:  SAP IAS or Microsoft Active Directory to SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2

Below is the flow diagram illustrating how users are synced from Microsoft Active Directory or/both SAP Identity Authentication IAS to SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 using IAS and IPS:

Flow Breakdown:

  1. Microsoft Active Directory (AD): Acts as the source of truth for user identities.
  2. SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS): Connects to AD via LDAP or Azure AD and serves as the identity provider.
  3. SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS): Pulls user data from IAS and pushes it to SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 using SCIM APIs.
  4. SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2: Receives user data via SCIM and provisions users automatically.

Identity Provisioning (IPS) Documentation - Target System 

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/target-sap-sales-cloud-and-sap-service-cloud 

Final Thoughts

The introduction of SCIM API support in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 marks a significant step toward modern identity management. By leveraging IAS and IPS, organizations can streamline user provisioning, enhance security, and ensure a consistent user experience across systems.

entry.title: Re: Migration Template "Warehouse Stock (new)" - Document...
entry.content:
Hi @talke 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Warehouse Stock (new) migration object is delivered as a standard template via the Migrate Your Data app.

  • The template only provides fields for material, plant, storage location, stock quantity, valuation, etc.
  • Document header text (HeaderText) is not included in the migration object structure.
  • Therefore, it cannot be filled directly via the migration template.

Please note the following standard system behaviour

  • When you migrate stock with the Warehouse Stock (new) object, the system creates an accounting document automatically.
  • However, the header text in MIGO (field BKTXT) is not populated from migration.
  • This is by design becuase migration postings are meant to be technical initial balances.

Here are possible options for you to consider

  1. Standard Limitation
    • You cannot enhance the delivered migration object in Public Cloud to add extra fields
    • Migration templates are SAP-delivered and not extensible.
  2. Alternatively, you can consider following this Workaround
    • If a header text is required for reporting/audit purposes, you could:
      • Post a separate FI journal entry with the desired header text, or
      • Use document number ranges or posting date indicators to differentiate migration postings.
    • For traceability, most customers use the posting date or posting period as migration indicator rather than relying on header text.

Please note that this requirement is not supported in Public Cloud. If it is a must-have, raise a request via SAP Influence Portal or consider a post-migration adjustment posting with the desired text.

For more information, consult the following references:

Migration Object: Warehouse Stock (New)

Data Migration Using Migrate Your Data App

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to update database
entry.content:
I have an application that was written in Visual Studio many years ago to create configuration files, with the option to print a copy via embedded Crystal Reports. I have recently had to slightly enhance the application to create addtional parameters, which I would like to include in the printed document.

After much work updating everything to the latest versions of the tools I now have everything working, except that I can't add the new features to the report. I mistakenly labelled some of the new items with spaces in their name like "Router Name".  That's how it appears in the Crystal Reports database so when I copy it into a report it doesn't print:

When I realised my mistake I corrected it in the calling form to "RouterName" but that doesn't reflect in the Crystal Reports database.

If I view the properties of MQTT in Database Expert it correctly shows the path to ReportDatSet.xsd.  However the new item MQTT doesn't appear in ReportDatSet.xsd even though it is referenced in ReportDatSet.cs:

ReportDataSetDesigner.cs defines partial class MQTTDataTable which includes this corrected code:

but it appears it is never called when I run the target application in debug mode and place breakpoints in it.  It is almost as if Crystal Reports takes a snapshot of the database at some time an never updates it.  How can I fix it?

entry.title: Re: Skip step in flexible PO workflow
entry.content:
Hi Henrike,

Thanks for the response. Yes, I was looking for the same what you have mentioned.

As already mentioned, BADI SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF allows only one condition ID, so we implemented step-level conditions within the above BADI implementation only as below.

1. Check if the variance is low enough to skip approvals ‚Äì For auto Approval.

2. Determine the maximum required approval level. Retrieving the current approval level.

3. Identify the latest completed workflow step from table SWWWIHEAD. When each workflow step is completed, we are saving PO number and step level in custom table for later validation usage. 4

. Count how many approvals have been completed and decide if workflow should proceed or not.

This way we could skip the workflow steps when not needed based on the level. However, we felt this is not the best way and not that use-friendly as we must carry out an extra step either deleting PO entries (from custom table ) or refreshing the level to 0 once the process is completed. Above extra step is required for the Restart workflow scenario.

Workflow Features for Purchase Orders | SAP Help Portal ‚Äì This blog says that we can extend the condition list with additional conditions. However, when I add multiple condition Id‚Äôs system will consider only the latest ID at Workflow step level. I cannot see the condition Id at Workflow definition level.

Below are multiple condition ID‚Äôs that are added in Implementation through Custom Logic app.

Our expectation is to have separate condition Id‚Äôs for Workflow definition and for Workflow step.

Thank you.

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: Re: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Yeah just chime to in, you are free to use whatever, especially for your own build applications, but each SAP cloud is different and uses different things.

  • IAG: P-userid
  • BTP: Whatever you set, often email (with UUID underwater I think)
  • BWZ: Use Global ID (UUID)
  • SAP_BASIS < 753: UserID 12 chars (for which the loginname field is intended)
  • SAP_BASIS > 753: Supports UUID

I assume this will be brought together more down the road. And yes you are pretty free to set whatever in the modular setup, except when you aren't (such as for joule or IAG).

entry.title: Community Feedback List - Disable features for new users
entry.content:
This is how the SAP Community home page looks like today

And it's clear that SAP Community admins are working on that - see Solved: Why Community moderator is not willing to moderate... - SAP Community

@AnnePetteroe wrote:

We were literally just a bit behind because the amount of abuse reports we received! And, we are, of course, in parallell also working on other measurements to prevent spam. More to follow soon.

Those are great news (I personally have reported dozens of times only in the last few months) and I feel the review process is quite fast. Anyway, as it's not clear exactly what the admins are planning, I'd like to give a suggestion that seems to hard - but should fix the spam issue: disabling features for new users. 

Before telling why, let me ask you to please engage in this post in case you agree with the idea so the admins and can know this would be acceptable by the real community users.

Let's see how the profile of such users spamming the community look like. As they will be very likely deleted soon, I am adding images and not links to their profile.

 

We don't need to talk about their content in detail. All those are asking money or talking about money in hindi.

The pattern is clear:

  • New user
  • Short / unreadable name
  • Most likely some weird e-mail address linked with their profile
  • Discoverer
  • Hindi
  • No profile picture
  • Many posts at once
  • Solutions are only for their own posts
  • Usually no blogs - only Q&A content
  • No kudos given/received
  • IP Address?

Inspired by StackOverflow, where you need to engage in order to receive permissions, I suggest that new users should not be able to do much on the community.

For example:

1) New users - read-only access
2) After adding information in your profile (picture, name, link with other social media account (such as Linkedin or Bluesky) then the user should receive some write access
3) Able to ask a single question which are not visible by default and some review will happen so it can be displayed (instead of making it visible and then reviewing after some user report)
4) Not able to ask a second question until the first is marked as solved
5) Not able to accept a solution on your own question
6) Not able to blog until giving X kudos on existing blogs

I hope this change wouldn't be hard to implement - I am not even talking about gamification - it's literally disabling features by default and granting them for real users based on clear criteria

This is way better than asking the community admins to review content.

entry.title: Warnings for exceeding limit on Working Time Accounts
entry.content:
Background

Time valuations generate time valuation results, which provide the basis upon which employees are paid for the time they record. But not all recorded time is paid out immediately. Sometimes the employee works more, sometimes less than the Planned Working Time. For storing this information, a ùêñùê®ùê´ùê§ùê¢ùêßùê† ùêìùê¢ùê¶ùêû ùêÄùêúùêúùê®ùêÆùêßùê≠ (WTA) is used. As you can imagine, the WTA moves up and down according to the actual working time. It should be more or less around Zero, but in the reality, it is not.

When the ùêõùêöùê•ùêöùêßùêúùêû ùêõùêûùêúùê®ùê¶ùêûùê¨ ùê≠ùê®ùê® ùê°ùê¢ùê†ùê° or low, the Employee, Manager and Time Admin must be aware about it to react. For this purpose, Warning messages or alerts are raised in time sheet.

Challenge/Problem

The ùê©ùê´ùê®ùêõùê•ùêûùê¶ is, that there are ùêùùê¢ùêüùêüùêûùê´ùêûùêßùê≠ ùê©ùêûùê´ùê¢ùê®ùêùùê¨, that must be considered. Most likely, at least for Germany, the Time Sheet is Monthly like the Payroll. There are daily limits that shall not be exceeded (e.g. 10 hours for common employees, 8 hours for underage). There are weekly limits, that shall not be exceeded in the long run (e.g. 48 hours). And the Working Time Account, that is configured Permanent. To bring this different period together, Time Containers are used.

Currently the maximum duration of Period Results is up to 12 Month. A common requirement for companies is that the Working Time Account shall not exceed a threshold (e.g. Standard Weekly Hours of the employee [quite often 40 Hours but depending on the specific employee]) permanently. While the Working Time Account can be configured as Permanent, the Time Container will be reset after 1 year. This leads to the Problem, that Warnings about exceeding thresholds is correct for a maximum of a year, after this they are wrong.

Example:

  • WTA 31.12.25 >>> 30 Hours
  • Time Container 31.12.25 >>> 30 Hours
  • WTA 01.01.26 >>> 30 Hours
  • Time Container 01.01.26 >>> 0 Hours
  • WTA exceeds 40 Hours on 01.02.26 --> Warning should happen
  • Time Container don‚Äôt exceed 40 Hours on 01.02.26 since it was reset --> no warning happens

As you can see from the example above, the WTA balance is checked on beginning of every month for Violation or warnings. But since the time container is reset on Jan 1st of every year in this example, the balance calculation can lead to incorrect results in 1st Jan and 1st Feb of 2026. We need to ensure continuation of balance check from previous year 2025 to next year 2026

This situation is described also in the influence request : https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/351707Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

How can we solve this challenge that the balance does not get reset every year and yet we send warning and alerts to employees, managers or admins?

Well, the solution lies in a Custom MDF and Integration centre which can do this job currently of a permanent time container until we build the complete logic in our time valuation engine to cater to this

Solution

We would need to define a custom MDF per user. The custom MDF tracks the balances of WTA every month and checks if the balance is > 40 hours. If yes, it then sends an alert to relevant users like employees , managers etc

Custom MDF structure

Essentially we need three fields

  • The external code is mapped to user
  • cust_AccountDate stores the current date when the balance is checked. For example, the beginning of the month Say Feb 1, 2026. This is useful also for reporting

In case you want to report on this MDF, then it can show the balance as of that date

  • cust_WTABalance stores the actual WTA balance of the employee. The alert is then run against this field by checking the value. If > 40, Alert is sent out for that month to required participants. Else it is ignored completely

 

To handle the alert mechanism, we will have an on Save rule and a Post Save Rule

OnSave Rule

On Post Save Rule (Alert Rule)

In the alert rule, you would also need a workflow config. In the workflow Config, Associate an appropriate workflow step in CC for whom you want to notify e.g.: Employee, manager etc

 

Integration Center:

How is the custom MDF triggered on a monthly basis? The answer is Integration Center. Well without Integration Center, our workarounds would have been lifeless :D.

So thanks a ton to those guys who invented/developed the integration centre üòä

The Integration centre is the final missing piece in the puzzle which runs on a monthly basis (beginning of the month). This then calls the creation/updating of custom MDF.

Once the MDF is saved/updated, the on save rules runs to check the balance of WTA Permanent account and then alert is processed

 

Set up the Integration Center Job for creating the custom MDF object data and triggering its rules
Create a User Scheduled Integration Center Report with below setting

Starting Entity is USER

Target Entity is the custom MDF that you have created

Drag and drop the user ID from the User entity to External Code (User field) of Custom MDF as shown above

Also, ensure that you use operation as Upsert Single/Multiple so that it updates the records of same user the next time

 

Next, its important to set appropriate filters as applicable. For example, if you want to run the Integration Center only for a certain population like German employees,

then add appropriate filers as applicable in filter section

 

Next, Schedule the job to send monthly notifications. Decide this frequency based on your needs.

Note: It is not recommended to schedule the Job daily due to performance impact it can create. Its better to schedule during non-business hours. Also keeping Performance in mind, It is important to select the filters such that you don‚Äôt perform the calculation for the whole user group and restrict it only to the required legal entities, Business Units or Departments

You are now done with the setup. Its time to test some scenarios

TESTING

Please note, to test this for different months, I had hardcoded the date for WTA check to 1st Jan 2025 , 1st July 2025, 1st Aug 2025 etc. But in general since IC runs every month, the today() function in the on save rule should pick the correct monthly date. So you don‚Äôt have to worry about this

 

Case 1 : Balance >= 40 hours

The employee has a balance of 54 hours as of Jan 1st 2025.

Please note that the balance from previous year i.e Dec 2024 is not reset and it‚Äôs a permanent account which is what we want for our scenario

Run the IC for Jan 1st 2025 (simulate) and we see the below

The custom MDF is also updated accordingly and the alert is sent out since the balance as of Jan 1st 2025 is >40

Email/Alert is sent out

Case 2: Balance <40 hours

Lets assume today is Aug 1st 2025, the WTA balance is now 36.5 hours as shown below

Lets run the IC now to see the behaviour

As you can see the custom MDF does not have account date (we would fill it only if >=40). And the balance is updated to 36.5. No Alert is sent in this case

Its flexible. If you want to store account date also for such cases, you could.

In summary, we can track Flex (WTA) account violations every month and the balance is tracked continuously or on a permanent basis without reset issue

Also, you could have this custom MDF embedded in the people profile page . With this the manager can navigate to custom MDF and check the details from profile page of the employee

Hope this helps in your implementation challenges. Do comment on the blog if you like it or have questions

Best Regards

Neelesh

entry.title: Does some SAP-provided sample code exist of how to fill the import structure for CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN?
entry.content:
Hi All!

We are currently on a system conversion journey from NW 7.50 to S/4HANA 2023 (see here, here and here for the background). During the custom code conversion we identified several programs which currently rely on maintenance of customer data via batch input or call transaction sessions to XD01, XD02 etc. There are also programs which do the same for vendors via XK01 or some function modules like vender_update.

We are already aware that these programs are basically not "salvagable" but that we need to create new logic utilizing the API class CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN instead. So, over the last couple of days I've searched and found some information on SAP Community (e.g. here or here), SAP Help (high level information) and OSS about how to work with the "unwieldy" import structure CVIS_EI_EXTERN  which goes along with the methods VALIDATE_SINGLE and MAINTAIN of that class. And I'm well aware that "unwieldy" doesn't really do that structure justice as its fully expanded hierarchy view with the many sub-structures and table types comes to about 32,000 lines in a spreadsheet! 

Given the complex inmport structure I'm a bit mystified why SAP on the one hand states that CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN is the way to go in an S/4HANA system for backend customer or vendor maintenance but then doesn't provide some actual sample or demo code which could be used as a starting point to make use of the class.

I'm really thankful for the code examples provided by fellow SAP Community members but am also wondering why we all are basically left to our own devices and have to re-invent the wheel while trying to come to grips with the deeply nested import structure - and without getting cross-eyed and/or confused while doing so!

What I also find somewhat interesting: the class has been around for a few years from what I can tell (there are at least mentions of it in SAP Community going back a few years), but there is no SAP-code at all in our S/4HANA system which actually makes use of it. At a guess, SAP should have code available used to internally test that the class works, before providing it in customer systems. So, I'm wondering if that code - if it does exist - could somehow be made available e.g. in a Github repository?

As you can tell, this perhaps isn't a typical Q&A thread looking simply for an answer to a question, but more the start of an actual discussion thread.

Thanks for reading and I'm looking forward to seeing your replies!

Cheers

B√§rbel

entry.title: üöÄ‚òÅÔ∏è Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud: A Business Transformation Journey
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna üôè I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

üìùIntroduction

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business environment, enterprises are under constant pressure to reduce costs üí∞, accelerate innovation üöÄ, and stay agile ‚ö°. Many organizations still run on-premise SAP HANA üóÑÔ∏è or ECC systems üè¢, which can limit scalability, slow analytics üìä, and increase IT overhead üõ†Ô∏è.

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud ‚òÅÔ∏è offers a solution: a cloud-native, scalable, and intelligent platform ü§ñ that not only modernizes your database but also unlocks new opportunities for business growth üìà, advanced analytics üìä, and AI-driven insights ü§ñ.

This blog explores the strategic advantages of moving to HANA Cloud, real-world scenarios, migration approaches, and how businesses can leverage this transformation for long-term success üåü.

1. Why Businesses Should Care About Migration

SAP HANA on-premise has been the backbone of enterprise IT for over a decade. But today, companies face challenges like:

  • üí∏Rising infrastructure and data center costs

  • üìâDifficulty scaling for seasonal or global demand

  • ‚ö°Pressure to innovate with real-time analytics and machine learning

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database upgrade ‚Äî it is a strategic enabler for business transformation:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èElastic scalability ‚Üí pay only for what you use

  • üí∞Lower TCO ‚Üí no hardware refresh, no patching overhead

  • ü§ñBuilt-in innovation ‚Üí multi-model (graph, JSON, geospatial), ML integration, Datasphere

  • üõ°Ô∏è Cloud-grade resilience ‚Üí HA, backups, encryption built in

üëâFor enterprises planning RISE with SAP, migration is often a key milestone. For GROW with SAP customers, HANA Cloud is already the default foundation.

2. A Real-World Story: Fashion Retailer Migrating During Peak Season

A large fashion retailer running ECC on HANA on-premise faced challenges during peak shopping seasons:

  • üè¨High traffic spikes during Black Friday, festive sales, and seasonal launches

  • üíæHardware was over-provisioned to handle peak loads but under-utilized the rest of the year

  • üìäAnalytics delays slowed decision-making for inventory replenishment, pricing, and promotions

By migrating to SAP HANA Cloud, the retailer was able to:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èScale compute resources elastically during high-demand weeks, then scale down during off-season

  • üìäIntegrate sales, inventory, and supply chain data in SAP Datasphere for real-time visibility

  • üí∞Reduce infrastructure costs by 25‚Äì30% while improving system performance

  • üõíOptimize promotional planning and inventory allocation by leveraging faster analytics on HANA Cloud

üëâResult: Smooth operations during peak shopping periods, lower costs, faster reporting, and improved customer satisfaction ‚Äî all while creating a foundation for a future move to S/4HANA Cloud.

3.üõ†Ô∏è‚ö° Migration Approach: Self-Service Tools for a Smooth Transition

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud can be complex, but SAP provides self-service migration tools to simplify the process, reduce risk, and speed up implementation.

1Ô∏è‚É£Assessment & Planning

  • üõ†Ô∏è Review current HANA workloads, database size, and custom code.

  • üìùDecide whether to migrate using sidecar (DB only) or full migration.

  • üîíMap compliance, security, and network requirements.

  • üìäIdentify business processes to migrate first (e.g., analytics sandbox or critical ERP data).

üëâReference: SAP HANA Cloud Migration Guide

2Ô∏è‚É£Execution with SAP Self-Service Migration Tools

SAP HANA Cloud Migration Cockpit / DMO (Database Migration Option):

  • üõ†Ô∏è Self-service migration: Provides a guided, wizard-based process for migrating data from on-premise HANA or BTP HANA Service to HANA Cloud.

  • ‚ö°Supports multiple migration scenarios:

    • ECC on HANA ‚Üí HANA Cloud (sidecar or full)

    • S/4HANA on-prem ‚Üí HANA Cloud

    • SAP HANA Service on BTP CF ‚Üí HANA Cloud

  • üîÑAutomated delta replication: Keeps source and target databases in sync until cutover.

  • üñ•Ô∏è Validation & monitoring: Allows pre-checks, logs, and real-time monitoring of migration progress.

  • üîóSeamless integration: Works with SAP tools like SLT/SDI, SUM/DMO, and SAP Cloud Transport.

Key Benefits:

  • Reduces manual steps and risk of errors.

  • Speeds up migration timeline.

  • Provides a self-service experience for IT teams, while still supporting SAP guidance and best practices.

üëâLearning resource: SAP Learning Journey ‚Äì Migrating SAP HANA to HANA Cloud

3Ô∏è‚É£Hands-On Simulation

  • üñ•Ô∏è Practice provisioning, configuring, and validating migration steps using SAP‚Äôs interactive simulation.

  • üëâTry it here: Enable Now Demo

4. Customer Scenarios: How Migration Helps Different Starting Points

üîπ1. Customers on ECC on HANA (on-premise)

Current State:

  • üóÑÔ∏è Running legacy ECC (not yet S/4HANA) with an SAP HANA database on-premise

  • üí∏Facing high infra + maintenance costs, limited innovation

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èThey can move their database layer first (sidecar or full migration) ‚Üí reduce infra costs immediately

  • üõ†Ô∏è This becomes a stepping stone to RISE with SAP (moving ERP to S/4HANA Cloud later is easier if DB is already on HANA Cloud)

  • üìäCan use HANA Cloud for analytics scenarios while still keeping ECC running on-prem

Scenario Architecture:

[üíª Users/Apps]
      |
      v
+-------------------+        Initial Load          +---------------------+
| üóÑÔ∏è ECC (ABAP stack)|----------------------------->| ‚òÅÔ∏è SAP HANA Cloud   |
+---------^---------+                              +----------^----------+
          |                                                 |
          |   Real-time Delta (SLT/SDI/DP Agent)            |
          +-----------------------------------------------> |
          |                                                 |
+---------+---------+                                       |
| üóÑÔ∏è SAP HANA (source)|<----- üîó VPN/Private Link/IPSec ---+
+-------------------+

üëâBenefit: Lower TCO now, smoother path to S/4HANA in future

üîπ2. Customers on S/4HANA On-Premise

Current State:

  • üóÑÔ∏è Already on S/4HANA, but hosted in on-premise data center

  • üí∏Often invested in large HANA appliances sized for peak loads

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èLift & shift the database layer to HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ‚ö°Elastic scaling ‚Üí no more overprovisioning

  • üìäCloud-native features like multi-model DB and Datasphere integration unlock new business insights

  • üõ°Ô∏è Reduces IT overhead (patching, HA setup, backup) ‚Äî handled by SAP

Scenario Architecture:

                +-------------------+
                | üóÑÔ∏è S/4HANA On-Prem |
                +---------^---------+
                          |  üõ†Ô∏è DMO / Export-Import
                          |  + Optional continuous replication (SLT/SDI)
                          v
                 -------------------------- üîó Secure Network -------------------------
                          v
                +---------+---------+       +---------------------+      +-----------+
                | ‚òÅÔ∏è SAP HANA Cloud  |<----->| üìä SAP Datasphere   |<---->| üìä SAC/BI |
                +---------^---------+       +----------^----------+      +-----^-----+
                          |                           |
                          | üõ†Ô∏è Destinations/XSUAA/CAP |
                          +---------------------------+

üëâBenefit: Modernized infrastructure, cost savings, easier innovation, and alignment with SAP‚Äôs cloud-first roadmap

üîπ3. Customers on SAP HANA Service on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry)

Current State:

  • üóÑÔ∏è Using managed HANA instances in BTP CF, often for extension apps or analytics

  • ‚ö†Ô∏èThis service is being phased out in favor of HANA Cloud

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èMigration ensures they‚Äôre on the strategic, supported database service

  • ‚ö°Feature parity and beyond (cloud-native scaling, multi-model)

  • üõ†Ô∏è Future-proof integration with BTP services like XSUAA, CAP, and Datasphere

Scenario Architecture:

 
+--------------------------------- BTP (CF) ---------------------------------+
|                                                                            |
|  +--------------------+           Data/Schema Move          +------------+ |
|  | üóÑÔ∏è HANA Service    |------------------------------------>| ‚òÅÔ∏è HANA Cloud |
|  +---------^----------+                                     +-----^------+ |
|            | App Bindings (CAP/UI5/XSA)                      |             |
|            +----------------------------- Rebind/Retarget ---+             |
+----------------------------------------------------------------------------+

‚ÄúEarlier SAP offered SAP HANA Service on BTP Cloud Foundry, but this has been fully retired and replaced by SAP HANA Cloud. Customers who were using HANA Service have already transitioned or are expected to migrate, since HANA Cloud is the only strategic database service supported by SAP.‚Äù

üëâBenefit: Mandatory move for long-term support + added innovation opportunities

üîπ4. Customers on Non-SAP Databases (Oracle, DB2, SQL Server) with ECC

Current State:

  • üóÑÔ∏è Legacy ECC on Oracle/DB2/SQL

  • üí∏DB costs + performance issues

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èMigrate directly to S/4HANA Cloud on HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ‚ö°Skip the intermediate step of on-prem HANA investment

  • üìäImmediately benefit from SAP‚Äôs innovation roadmap

Scenario Architecture:

[üóÑÔ∏è Legacy ECC on Non-SAP DB] ---- Extract (ETL/LTMC) ---+
                                                        |
                                                        v
                                             +---------------------+
                                             | ‚òÅÔ∏è S/4HANA Cloud    |
                                             +----------^----------+
                                                        |
                                             Standard Content & Mapping
                                                        |
                                                        v
                                             +---------------------+
                                             | ‚òÅÔ∏è SAP HANA Cloud    |
                                             +---------------------+

üëâBenefit: Leapfrog into cloud ERP without double investment

5. Migration Challenges & How to Overcome Them

While migrating to SAP HANA Cloud brings huge benefits, enterprises may face some challenges. Here‚Äôs what to watch for:

  • üîÑData Volume & Delta Replication

    • Large datasets can slow migration.

    • Mitigation: Use SLT/SDI for incremental replication and pre-validate data mapping.

  • üîêSecurity & Compliance

    • Sensitive business data needs encryption in transit and proper role mapping.

    • Mitigation: Configure VPN/Private Link, enforce identity/auth with XSUAA, and follow SAP security guidelines.

  • üõ†Ô∏è Custom ABAP Code & Extensions

    • Custom programs may have compatibility issues with HANA Cloud.

    • Mitigation: Test custom code in sandbox or trial HANA Cloud before cutover.

  • ‚ö°Application & Integration Dependencies

    • Connected apps or BI tools need retargeting.

    • Mitigation: Rebind or redirect connections to HANA Cloud and Datasphere endpoints.

  • ‚è±Ô∏è Downtime & Cutover Planning

    • Minimizing business disruption is critical.

    • Mitigation: Plan cutover during off-peak periods, validate all delta loads, and communicate with stakeholders.

6. How This Fits with RISE & GROW with SAP

  • üåüRISE with SAP ‚Üí Migration is a natural step for existing ERP customers moving to S/4HANA Cloud

  • üå±GROW with SAP ‚Üí Net-new cloud ERP customers start directly on HANA Cloud and benefit from innovation immediately

7. Business Outcomes After Migration

  • üí∞30‚Äì40% lower infrastructure costs

  • ‚ö°Faster innovation cycles with ML, JSON, graph, and Datasphere integration

  • üåêGlobal reach through geo-replication

  • üõ°Ô∏è Operational resilience with automated HA and backups

8. Future Roadmap / Innovation After Migration

After migration, enterprises can unlock new business capabilities on HANA Cloud:

  • ü§ñMachine Learning & Predictive Analytics

    • Forecast demand, optimize inventory, and personalize offers in retail.

  • üåêReal-Time Data Integration with Datasphere

    • Connect multiple cloud and on-premise sources for unified analytics.

  • ‚ö°Cloud-Native Applications

    • Build extensions using SAP CAP, integrate with Fiori/UI5 apps, and leverage BTP services.

  • üõ†Ô∏è Automation & RPA

    • Automate repetitive processes and alerts for faster operational response.

  • üöÄFuture-Ready ERP

    • Smooth path to S/4HANA Cloud or advanced SAP solutions under RISE with SAP.

Key Takeaways

  • üöÄMigration to SAP HANA Cloud is strategic, not just technical

  • üõ†Ô∏è Start with analytics or sandbox workloads first

  • üñ•Ô∏è Use SAP guides + Enable Now simulation to de-risk projects

  • üåüAlign migration with your RISE roadmap for long-term gains

entry.title: Re: BDCQ - Finance - Needs to be in sync with SAP Best Pr...
entry.content:
Hello @KP_2025 

Thank you for your question. Hope this still provides some support.

you are correct, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the BDCQs sometimes show different descriptions for the same scope item compared to SAP Best Practices scope item documentation.

    • An example is: Scope Item 1QM is officially Advanced Financial Operations in the Best Practices Explorer. In the Finance BDCQ, the same scope item may still appear with the older description (Credit Evaluation and Management).

Here is why the mismatch tends to happen

  • BDCQs are maintained in Central Business Configuration. However, the scope item descriptions in Central Business Configuration may lag behind updates in the Best Practices Explorer.
  • The technical scope item ID (e.g. 1QM) is always the reliable reference, even if the wording differs.

Here is what I recommend

  • Always rely on the scope item ID (e.g. 1QM), not only the text description, when mapping BDCQ to Best Practices.
  • If the mismatch causes confusion whilst carrying out your project work, SAP recommends raising a support incident under component XX-S4C-OPR so that the CBC team can synchronize the descriptions with the latest Best Practice content.

The following references will provide further details:

Central Business Configuration ‚Äì Business Driven Configuration Questionnaires

SAP Best Practices Explorer ‚Äì Scope Items

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Down payments for Non-Trade Supplier are not applicab...
entry.content:
Hello @mbanggo 

This behaviour is expected in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public. The Manage Down Payment Request app Only Supports suppliers connected to trade payables' reconciliation accounts.

Non-trade suppliers, such as those linked to other liabilities, are excluded. Consequently, you cannot create down payment requests for them in the standard app.

Possible Workarounds

Manual posting, Use the Post Outgoing Payments (F1612) or Post General Journal Entries (F0718) app to generate the down payment directly and later offset it against the final payment invoice.

Supplier Invoice Request. Alternatively, you can start the payment manually, although this is not a genuine down payment request.

Extension approach: If down payments for Non-Trade suppliers occur frequently, you can consider a custom RAP app or workflow in SAP BTP or In-App Extensibility to replicate the request logic.

Process review. Some customers handle this by reclassifying certain suppliers under trade reconciliation accounts or by using a dummy PO to align with standard functionality.

KBA 3226814 ‚Äì Restrictions in Manage Down Payment Requests

Down payments through the Manage Down Payment Request app are available only for Trade Suppliers. For Non-Trade Suppliers, you must use manual postings or develop an extension if this is a recurring need.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Number Prefixing
entry.content:
Hello @MikaelaWard 

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can differentiate purchase order numbers by assigning distinct number range intervals to various PO document types. This is the standard approach for distinguishing between Stock, Non-Stock, and Service POs.

Configuring instructions

Define Number Ranges for Purchasing Documents

    • Create new number range intervals according to your business needs: 45xxxxxx for Services, 46xxxxxx for Non-Stock

Assign Number Ranges to Document Types

  • Assign each interval to a PO document type. If needed, create custom PO document types for Stock, Non-Stock, Service and link them to their own number ranges.

Notes / Special cases

This approach works for operational purchase orders.F2872 App

Alphabetic number ranges are only relevant for Central Purchase Orders F3292 App(Central Procurement scenario. See KBA 3596398 a for details, though these are not required for standard Pos

You cannot filter number ranges directly by PO created via MRP vs. manually; instead, the differentiation should be based on the PO document type. Assigning unique number ranges to different document types enables you to clearly distinguish between them.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Custom button calling a custom screen
entry.content:
Hello @mollopes 

Yes, it‚Äôs possible, but with RAP and OData V4, you won‚Äôt create a completely new screen the way we did in old dynpros.

In Fiori Elements, you typically address this in three ways, depending on how different that second screen truly needs to be.

Recommended bound action with parameters for better results.

    • You specify an action in your RAP behaviour by providing input parameters.
    • Fiori Elements makes it really easy by automatically showing a button and a parameter dialogue whenever the user clicks on it.
    • The user fills in additional fields, and you process them in your RAP handler.
    • This provides a pop-up screen without the need to build a new UI.

Navigation to another page or app

  • If you need a separate page, you can use intent-based navigation between two Fiori Elements apps or to a freestyle app.
  • You pass the current entity key as context, so the second app loads the same data plus extra fields.

Custom pop-up through controller extension

    • Add a custom action on the Object Page and open a UI5 dialogue with your own layout.
    • Within that dialogue, you can gather additional input and then manually invoke your RAP action.
    • Useful if you want more control over the UI than the standard action-parameter dialogue.

In the S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can‚Äôt create custom database screens or dynpros, so these patterns are the supported approach. For your use case, the same data, plus new fields and process option 1, is the simplest one, with a single button, a single dialogue, and all in line with standards.

Refer to below SAP useful documentation

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

SAP Help ‚ÄìABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

SAP Help ‚Äì Late Numbering in RAP

SAP Help-ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Issue with BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1 ‚Äì Reservation Not...
entry.content:
Hello @taher123 

Thank you for the information. Since you are using S/4HANA Public Cloud

MB23 isn‚Äôt available on Public Cloud. Use the Fiori apps, such as Manage Material Reservations (F7279), to create or view reservations.

BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1 is not a released API in Public Cloud (ABAP Cloud). Even if it returns success, it is not supported, and the document will not appear in the standard Fiori apps.

Alternative supported options.

  1. UI: Create/check reservations in Manage Material Reservations and related display/change apps.
  2. Integration and automation: Utilise the publicly available API for reservations, provided by the SAP API Business Accelerator Hub (A2X OData/REST). Access it through your extension (RAP/BTP Cloud SDK).)
  3. Auth check: Confirm your user has access to the Inventory Management business catalogues that include the reservation apps.

If you share the API you plan to call, I can provide a basic example payload, endpoint, and Cloud SDK snippet along with the exact Fiori app IDs.

With kind regards
Chuma

entry.title: Unified Successor for All- GRC Access Control 12.0, Process Control 12.0, UI Masking & More!!
entry.content:
As organizations accelerate their digital transformation with SAP S/4HANA- Governance, Risk and compliance (GRC) must evolve in parallel. To support this journey, SAP is introducing the next generation of its GRC solution: SAP GRC for HANA 2026.

This release marks a significant milestone, aligning SAP's GRC capabilities with the performance, scalability, and innovation of the SAP HANA platform. Designed natively for S/4HANA environments, GRC for HANA 2026 empowers businesses to manage risk, enforce compliance, and ensure access security with greater efficiency and intelligence.

What‚Äôs New in SAP GRC for HANA 2026:

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 builds on the proven foundation of GRC 12 while introducing new enhancements designed for modern enterprises:

SAP Fiori 3 User Experience: A modernized, intuitive user interface offers a consistent and streamlined experience across GRC modules, increasing user adoption and simplifying daily operations.

HANA-Native Performance: Leverages SAP HANA‚Äôs in-memory capabilities to enable faster data processing, real-time analytics, and scalable performance across large enterprise landscapes.

Enhanced Integration : Improved connectivity with cloud services, hybrid systems, and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), enabling end-to-end risk visibility and control across environments.

AI-Driven Insights : Initial capabilities in machine learning and automation are being introduced to assist with access pattern analysis, risk identification, and anomaly detection.

Future-Ready Architecture: Built to support S/4HANA 2025 and beyond, with a roadmap aligned to SAP‚Äôs long-term strategy, ensuring your GRC investment is secure for the next decade.

Core Modules Supported: SAP GRC for HANA 2026 continues to support the full suite of core GRC modules, now optimized for the new platform:

Access Control ‚Äì Manage user access, enforce SoD policies, and streamline provisioning with enhanced performance and usability.

Process Control ‚Äì Automate control testing, monitor compliance in real-time, and gain greater transparency into internal controls.

Risk Management ‚Äì Identify, assess, and respond to risks across the enterprise with improved analytics and integration.

Deployment and Compatibility- SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is designed to integrate seamlessly into both on-premise and cloud-centric S/4HANA landscapes. Whether you are migrating from GRC 12 or planning a greenfield implementation, the platform supports flexible deployment models to meet your organizational needs.

Key Outliners for the Upgrade Planning:

  • Modern, intuitive UX for business users and compliance teams
  • Faster risk and control analysis with real-time processing
  • Future-proof compliance aligned with SAP‚Äôs product roadmap
  • Scalable architecture for complex enterprise environments
  • Enhanced support for hybrid and cloud-first operations

As digital ecosystems grow more complex, organizations need a GRC platform that keeps pace. SAP GRC for HANA 2026 offers a robust, intelligent, and scalable solution for the next generation of compliance and risk management.

If you are a SAP MaxAttention, ActiveAttention Customer- please contact your Technical Quality Manager else the appropriate SAP Representative can be contacted.

SAP Americas Premium Engagements & Advisory (PE&A) Lead: Sam Minocha

entry.title: Clarification on Transporting Internal Career Site Configuration
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We have already transported the External Career Site from QA to Production, and it is currently live in Production.

Now, the requirement is to transport only the Internal Career Site configuration from QA to Production. The External Career Site in QA and Production have different configurations, so we do not want to overwrite or impact the external site that is already live in Production.

My question is:

  • Can we use the Import and Export tool in Career Site Builder to transport only the Internal Career Site configuration from QA to Production?

  • Or will this process also impact the existing External Career Site that is live in Production?

Your guidance on the best approach would be highly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: No pg_hba.conf entry for host in SAP CF PostgreSQL Hy...
entry.content:
hello,
 I also faced the same error in NestJS and TypeORM  with postgres of BTP 
 and this is my solution 

 

@Module({})
export class DatabaseModuleBTP {
  static async forRoot(): Promise<DynamicModule> {
    const creds = JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES || '{}')["postgresql-db"][0].credentials;
    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
    return {
      module: DatabaseModuleBTP,
      imports: [
        TypeOrmModule.forRoot({
          type: 'postgres',
          host: creds.hostname,
          port: Number(creds.port),
          username: creds.username,
          password: creds.password,
          database: creds.dbname,
          ssl: {
            rejectUnauthorized: true,
            ca: creds.sslrootcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
            cert: creds.sslcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
          },

          entities: [__dirname + '/../**/*.entity{.ts,.js}'],
          synchronize: true,
          logging: ['query', 'error', 'log', 'warn', 'info'],
          autoLoadEntities: true,
        }),
      ],
    };
  }
}

entry.title: Re: BTP NodeJS Express API with PostgreSQL Database Conne...
entry.content:
I got the solution of NestJS and TypeORM BTP postgres

import { DynamicModule, Module } from '@nestjs/common';
import { TypeOrmModule } from '@nestjs/typeorm';

@Module({})
export class DatabaseModuleBTP {
  static async forRoot(): Promise<DynamicModule> {
    const creds = JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES || '{}')["postgresql-db"][0].credentials;
    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
    return {
      module: DatabaseModuleBTP,
      imports: [
        TypeOrmModule.forRoot({
          type: 'postgres',
          host: creds.hostname,
          port: Number(creds.port),
          username: creds.username,
          password: creds.password,
          database: creds.dbname,
          ssl: {
            rejectUnauthorized: true,
            ca: creds.sslrootcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
            cert: creds.sslcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
          },

          entities: [__dirname + '/../**/*.entity{.ts,.js}'],
          synchronize: true,
          logging: ['query', 'error', 'log', 'warn', 'info'],
          autoLoadEntities: true,
        }),
      ],
    };
  }
}‚Äã

entry.title: Commerce Automation - MIRO Invoice to SAP Business network
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Could someone please confirm, in Ariba Commerce Automation, do we have a scenario where we will be able to send the MIRO Invoice to SAP Business Network?

Per our understanding of the Standard Commerce Automation scenarios. When we send a PO to SAP Business network from S/4HANA Private Cloud ERP or SAP ECC. Supplier can submit the invoice from Network and that will create the Invoice in S/4 Automatically, this is standard and working perfectly fine for us. In this case, if the supplier submits a Paper invoice to AP team, can they create invoice through MIRO T.Code in SAP and send the invoice to SAP business network? Can some please confirm if this channel is available by standard?

The other channel for sending invoice from SAP to SAP Business network what we have seen is through the ERS (Evaluated Receipt Settlement), by this channel, once the PO is created with the ERS flag at the line-item level, the invoice will be generated in SAP through the MRRL T.Code and these invoices will have the ERS output type which will then be sent to Network. So our question is, to send invoices from SAP to SAP Business network, is this the only channel, can we not send the invoices from SAP to Business Network via the MIRO at all? 

Thanks,
Velu

#SAPS/4HANA

entry.title: Re: SAP RAP Events local Consumption
entry.content:
Hello @AshishPandey 

Thanks for the details. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (ABAP environment), RAP business object events, such as R_PurchaseOrderTP ‚Üí Created, are triggered at commit. If your event binding is set to queued/AT_COMMIT delivery, the handler executes asynchronously after the commit. During debugging, you typically wait at that point, which can make it seem as though the event only functions in debug mode.

Here‚Äôs a quick way to check it

Event Binding (ADT)

  • Open the Event Binding of R_PurchaseOrderTP.
  • For testing, set Delivery to IMMEDIATE and activate it. If it fires instantly, the previous behaviour was simply due to async timing.

Binding & Filters

  • Consumer type = Local Handler; Event = Created for R_PurchaseOrderTP.
  • Make sure no filter excludes your test data.

Draft vs. Active save

  • Fiori Purchase Order creation is draft based. The Created event triggers upon activation or final save, like Order, not while still in draft.

Handler class

  • Class is active and ABAP Cloud‚Äìcompliant.
  • Implements the RAP event handler interface and method signature accurately, for instance:

CLASS zcl_po_evthdlr DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    INTERFACES if_abap_behavior_event_handler.

    METHODS on_created FOR EVENTS created OF r_purchaseordertp

      IMPORTING keys.

ENDCLASS.

If you keep AT_COMMIT

  • Asynchronous delivery uses bgRFC (background Remote Function Call), which is managed in the Public Cloud. Wait a few seconds and check your application logs, such as the BAL application log, to verify it has been executed.

Do you need to run any extra checks on the program?
No. There‚Äôs nothing to schedule beyond activating the Event Binding. With IMMEDIATE, the handler runs in the same Logical Unit of Work; with AT_COMMIT, it‚Äôs processed automatically.

Develop Event-Based Integration-SAP Help 

ABAP Keyword Doc ‚Äì METHODS ‚Ä¶ FOR ENTITY EVENT (handler signature for RAP events) 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Functional area derivation using custom logic in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Functional areas in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are organizational units used for classifying expenses by their nature rather than by operational or geographical divisions. They serve as a key component in cost-of-sales accounting and enable businesses to prepare segmental financial statements for compliance and decision-making purposes. The derivation of functional areas is determined based on the sequence as explained here. In this short blog post, I would like to cover a practical example of how the functional area derivation works using a custom logic substitution rule, which is the last sequence step of the derivation logic. In this demo example, the use case is that the derivation should take place only for the company code 0800, and the default functional area will be substituted by a target functional area which is entered in a custom field of a professional services customer project. The prerequisite is creating and enabling the custom field YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd  in the business context "Work Package".

Step 1:

Create a custom logic implementation for the Extension Point FIN_CODING_BLOCK_SUBSTITUTION

Add the following code: in this example, if the Company Code 0800 is used, the custom logic will substitute the default functional area with the functional area entered by the user into the custom field.

* Note: please always copy the values from input to output first before

* any substitutions, otherwise, the initial values from the output will

* be used for substitutions!!

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING codingblockitem TO codingblockitemout.

 

DATA lv_project_target_fa type STRING.

*Only valid for customer projects, as the custom field is created in this context

IF codingblockitem-companycode = '0800'.

    SELECT YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd FROM I_WORKPACKAGE

    INTO @LV_project_target_fa

    WHERE WORKPACKAGE = @codingblockitem-wbselementexternalid.

    ENDSELECT.

    "If the custom field value if empty, no substitution

    If  lv_project_target_fa IS INITIAL.

        EXIT.

    ELSE.

        codingblockitemout-functionalarea = lv_project_target_fa.

        substitutiondone = abap_true.

    ENDIF.

ENDIF.

Next, create the substitution rule for this custom logic to be executed. In the ‚ÄúManage Substitution/Validation Rules ‚Äì Journal Entries‚Äù app, create a new rule for the business context Coding Block as follows:

 

The precondition determines in which cases the substitution rule will be triggered ‚Äì in our demo use case, we want the rule to trigger only when the source functional area is equal to 'YB25'. The substitution rule itself simply maps the target field value to the value of the source field functional area (which will be set to a new value during the runtime of the custom logic). So essentially, if the customer project custom field has a target functional area 'YB24' maintained, the default functional area YB25 will be replaced by 'YB24'.

Once this is done, we can conduct a quick test to validate the result. The default functional area determined is YB25, and for our test project XDT0031, the custom field has been maintained with YB24 as the target functional area. After completing a test time booking for the project, the derivation result can be successfully validated in the "Display Line Items in General Ledger" app:

entry.title: Re: Link between customer details and material
entry.content:
SELECT
FROM vbak AS sh "Sales Document: Header Data
INNER JOIN vbap AS si "Sales Document: Item Data
ON sh~vbeln = si~vbeln
INNER JOIN mara AS mat "General Material Data
ON si~matnr = mat~matnr
INNER JOIN knvv AS custsalesorg "Customer Master Sales Data
ON sh~vkorg = custsalesorg~vkorg AND
sh~vtweg = custsalesorg~vtweg AND
sh~spart = custsalesorg~spart AND
sh~kunnr = custsalesorg~kunnr
FIELDS    sh~vbeln AS sales_order,
 mat~matnr AS material ,
    custsalesorg~kunnr AS customer,
     custsalesorg~vkorg AS salesorg,
       custsalesorg~vtweg AS distchannel,
         custsalesorg~spart AS division
          INTO TABLE @DATA(l_i_itab)
           UP TO 10 ROWS.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
ENDIF.

 Regards, 
Aniketh B R

entry.title: Re: BRF+
entry.content:
NW ABAP Business Rule Framework (BRFplus)  is a rule engine and framework, that allows you to define, manage, and execute business rules separately from application code.

Instead of hardcoding business logic inside ABAP programs, BRF+ provides a declarative, model-driven approach to implement and maintain rules, making business processes more flexible and easier to adapt to changes.

Key Features of SAP BRF+:

  • Centralized Rule Management
    Rules are stored in a central repository, allowing reuse across multiple applications.

  • Graphical & User-Friendly Interface
    Business users and functional consultants (not only developers) can model rules using a browser-based UI (decision tables, decision trees, formulas, expressions, etc.).

  • Some of the expressions from which rules can be derived are :

    • Decision tables ( Similar to Excel tables for conditions and results)

    • Formulas (mathematical or logical expressions)

    • Decision trees (Hierarchial value derivation based on boolean expression result true or false) 

    • Case statements (Similar to abap case staments, alternative for an else-if ladder )

  • Integration with ABAP Applications
    Rules can be called from ABAP code via generated function modules.
    Example: VAT calculation, eligibility checks, or workflow decisions.

  • Transportable & Versionable
    Rules can be moved between SAP systems (Dev ->QA ->Preprod-> Prod) like standard customizing. Versions help track changes.

  • Separation of Concerns
    IT builds the framework; business experts manage the rules. This speeds up adaptation to new regulations or policies.

    Example Use Cases:

    • Tax determination (e.g., in SAP Tax and Revenue Management)

    • Credit checks in financial transactions

    • Claim eligibility in insurance

    • Workflow approvals based on configurable rules

    • Pricing, discounts, and surcharges in sales. 



    Inorder to create a simple BRF+ application from scratch please refer blog bost below :  


    Create a Simple Business Rule Framwork Plus application from scratch  


    Regards, 

    Aniketh B R

entry.title: Re: tables in BRF plus
entry.content:
For fetching name of any BRF+ object query the table : FDT_ADMN_0000

with OBJECT_TYPE field being : 
AP for Application
CA for Catalog
DO for Data Object
EX for Expression
FI for Filter
FU for Function
RS for Ruleset

For decision table use OBJECT_TYPE = EX since Decision table is also an expression. 


Regards, 

Aniketh B R

entry.title: Re: Using BRF plus
entry.content:
Just to add on to the previous answers posted by community members, Once a BRF+ Function is activated, inorder to generate ABAP Code we have two ways of ABAP code generation from the BRF+ UI itself as shown in the image below










 

We can either create a Function module with BRF generated structures/tables/ddic objects part of signature, later call the function module. Other way around we can create a code template for which the system generates the abap code, in which we have replace context and result objects as mentioned in the generated code. 


In summary for the second part of question do you need ABAP knowledge for utlizing BRF+, For the initial setup, calling BRF+ application via workflow classes, in that case abap knowledge is required. Once the connectivity is maintained, post that its purely a functional activity to maintain the rules and derive additional rules/ validations. I hope this helped. 


Regards, 

Aniketh B R

entry.title: Effective Axios Error Logging for Robust SAP Integrations
entry.content:
Comparing Error Responses: Which One Aids Debugging Better?

Suppose we have executed an HTTP request using CAP and it fails. Below are two logged error responses:

1st Scenario:

2nd Scenario:


It‚Äôs immediately clear which version is easier to debug and helps us quickly identify the reason for the failure.

When building SAP extensions or integrations, developers often rely on Axios for handling HTTP requests. While Axios simplifies API communication, error handling can quickly become a challenge‚Äîespecially when debugging complex integration scenarios.

In many projects, errors are either logged with too little detail (just a generic message) or with too much raw data, making debugging time-consuming. To improve maintainability and speed up root cause analysis, we need a structured error logging mechanism.

Why Structured Error Logging Matters

In enterprise scenarios like SAP SuccessFactors or SAP BTP service integrations, requests often involve multiple systems. Without detailed error insights, you might only see:

Error: Request failed with status code 400

 But what you really need is:

  • Which endpoint failed?

  • What payload was sent?

  • What was the response from the server?

  • Was there any custom error code attached?

This is where a structured error handling approach becomes invaluable.

Implementation: A Structured Axios Error Logger

Here‚Äôs a reusable utility function you can plug into your Node.js / TypeScript projects:

public getAxiosErrorObject(error: any) {
  if (error.isAxiosError) {
    const errorObj = {
      message: error.message || 'An error occurred during the request.',
      code: error.code || 'UNKNOWN',
      status: error.response ? error.response.status : 'No Status',
      statusText: error.response ? error.response.statusText : 'No Status Text',
      requestData: error.config ? error.config.data : 'No Request Data',
      requestMethod: error.config ? error.config.method : 'No Request Method',
      requestUrl: error.config ? error.config.url : 'No Request URL',
      responseData: error.response ? error.response.data : 'No Response Data'
    };
    return errorObj;
  }
  return {
    message: error.message || 'An unknown error occurred',
    stack: error.stack || 'No Stack Trace'
  };
}

 

How It Works

  • Checks if it‚Äôs an Axios error
    Axios sets error.isAxiosError = true. This allows us to distinguish between HTTP request errors and other runtime issues.

  • Captures request details
    The request URL, method, and payload are logged, which is crucial for reproducing and debugging issues.

  • Captures response details
    If the server responded, we extract the status code, status text, and response body.

  • Fallback for non-Axios errors
    In cases where the error didn‚Äôt come from Axios (e.g., runtime exceptions), we still log a meaningful message and stack trace.

Example Usage

try {
  const response = await axios.post('/api/employees', { name: 'Sahil M' });
  console.log(response.data);
} catch (error) {
  const structuredError = this.getAxiosErrorObject(error);
  console.error('API Error:', structuredError);
}

Example Output  

{
  "message": "Request failed with status code 400",
  "code": "ERR_BAD_REQUEST",
  "status": 400,
  "statusText": "Bad Request",
  "requestData": "{\"name\":\"Sahil M\"}",
  "requestMethod": "post",
  "requestUrl": "/api/employees",
  "responseData": {
    "error": "Invalid employee data"
  }
}

Best Practices

  1. Avoid logging sensitive data
    When logging request payloads, ensure no confidential fields (e.g., passwords, tokens) are exposed.

  2. Integrate with monitoring tools
    Forward structured error logs to tools like SAP Cloud Logging for central monitoring.

  3. Normalize error structure
    Use this function as a single source of truth for error logging across your project, ensuring consistent logs.

  4. Enhance with correlation IDs
    In SAP integrations, add transaction or correlation IDs to quickly trace requests across systems.

entry.title: Re: VIES VAT Validation using BRF+ in MDG BP
entry.content:
Hi @deepakmk1996 ,

This can be acheived through BRF+, Please follow the steps given below: 

1. Navigate to transaction USMD_RULE (Definition of rules for validations and derivations)

2. Enter the data model, since here its Business partner requirement, enter BP

3. Under FMDM_MODEL_BP application expand function CHECK_ENTITY

4.  Create a function with naming convention CHECK_<Entity_Name> (Entity name you can get to know using transaction MDGIMG)

5. Add context data object ( select structure based on the entity ) 

6. Create a Ruleset for the function 

7. Define you validation rule, additionally you can create an action log message and assign to result if you want to perform log message action in the MDG UI screen if validation fails thereby informing user via warning or error message. 

Regards, 
Aniketh B R

entry.title: Re: BAPI to read table CRMS4D_EXT_REF in SAP S4 HANA
entry.content:
Hello @Gayatri_Bagde 

Thanks for the detailed notes. I reviewed your setup, and the 403 responses are expected given how each API is authenticated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Why do two work while the others do not?

  • Some APIs are intended for end users and support SAML bearer (principal propagation). Examples include Business Partner, Sales Order, and Product. These require the appropriate business roles and, importantly, maintained restrictions such as Sales Organisation, Plant, and Storage Location. When restrictions are set to 'No Access', metadata is loaded, but data reads return a 403 error.
  • Other APIs are technical or system-focused and do not accept SAML bearer tokens. Examples in your case include Material Stock and Sales Organisation. These must be accessed using a Communication User via a Communication Arrangement with Basic authentication or a client certificate. Assigning more roles to a human user will not alter this behaviour.

What needs to be changed

Keep SAML bearer for end-user APIs

    • Keep using your SAML destination for Business Partner, Sales Order, and Product.
    • In Manage Business Roles, open the roles you've assigned and configure Restrictions. Set Read and Value Help to either Restricted or Unrestricted, then specify the allowed values for Sales Org, Plant, and Storage Location.
    • If your trust uses email as the NameID, add this to the BTP destination:
      nameIdFormat = urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:emailAddress.

Change the technical APIs to a Communication User.

    • For Material Stock and Sales Organisation, create a Communication User, Communication System, and Communication Arrangement for each API. communication scenario in S/4HANA Cloud.
    • Create a separate destination in BTP with Authentication = BasicAuthentication (or client certificate) that points to the API base URL.
    • Use this Basic or x509 destination exclusively for specific APIs in your UI5 app.

Example destination (Basic)

Name = S4C_MaterialStock_Basic

Type = HTTP

URL  = https://<your-s4c-host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/

Authentication = BasicAuthentication

User = <COMM_USER>

Password = <********>

Quick review of your list

  • Business Partner, Sales Order, Product: SAML bearer is acceptable once role restrictions are applied.
  • Material Stock, Sales Organisation: call with a Communication User via a Basic or x509 destination.

If you'd like, I can map an entire API end-to-end, providing you with a template that includes the communication scenario to activate, the specific role restrictions to maintain, and the destination properties to use in BTP.

Material Stock Integration (SAP_COM_0164)-SAP Help

3445942 - UI Development in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Frequently Asked Questions

With kind regards
Chuma

entry.title: Re: VIES VAT Validation using BRF+ in MDG BP
entry.content: Ah, got it! Here‚Äôs a revised version with Phonexa naturally mentioned: --- Wow, this is a tricky one! I‚Äôd suggest trying to leverage BRF+ for the VIES VAT check since it keeps things more ‚Äúlow-code‚Äù for the business side. You can set up a BRF+ function to validate the VAT number and integrate it into the MDG BP rules so it runs automatically when creating or updating a business partner. I‚Äôve seen teams combine this with USMD\_RULE\_SERVICE just to cover edge cases, and it actually works pretty smoothly. On a side note, we‚Äôve been using Phonexa internally to track client requests and workflows, and having tools like that really helps keep everything organized while testing setups like this. Definitely take some time to test all scenarios, but this approach avoids heavy custom coding and keeps everything maintainable.
